newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican crude ports remain shut with ships waiting.
newsitem.headline: Mexican crude ports remain shut with ships waiting.

text.p: Two of Mexico's main crude ports remained closed for a third day with tankers waiting to load and set sail, port officials said on Monday.

Dos Bocas and Pajaritos closed late Saturday because of storms in the Gulf of Mexico and were still shut as of 7 p.m. on Monday (0000 GMT on Tuesday). Officials told Reuters the ports would be unlikely to open before late Tuesday.
"It's very ugly here. I think we will stay closed through Wednesday," a Pajaritos official told Reuters. Winds at the terminals were between 40 and 50 kmh at the ports, with waves up to 12 feet high.

At Dos Bocas, a port captain said two crude tankers were waiting for weather conditions to improve before setting sail. Weather at the ports will be reviewed at 7 a.m., and a decision will be made on whether to open the terminals. U.S.-bound

John Young has been held up during the three-day closure, unable to load a contracted 1.45 million barrels of Maya heavy crude, and U.S. Bona Spring was waiting to load 525,000 barrels of Maya, he said.

Eight tankers were stuck waiting to enter Pajaritos and eight were waiting to leave, according to a port official. Of the arriving ships, he said five were from state oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), while four of the ships waiting to sail were Pemex's.
Pemex's largest crude port, Cayo Arcas, was reported open at 7:20 a.m. on Monday after shutting at 7:20 p.m. on Saturday.
Cayo Arcas shipped an average 576,300 barrels per day (bpd) of crude in 1996, while Dos Bocas shipped 505,900 bpd and Pajaritos shipped about 416,200 bpd, according to Pemex.
